questions.text: A middle-aged patient who underwent perimetry had the following visual field defect. What is the site of the lesion?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The image given above shows a bitemporal hemianopsia visual field defect, caused due to a lesion at the optic chiasma.

 

VISUAL PATHWAY - Eye (Retina) → Optic Nerve → Optic Chiasm → Optic Tract → Lateral Geniculate Nucleus → Optic Radiation → Visual Cortex

 

  1. Eye (Retina): Light enters the eye and is captured by photoreceptor cells in the retina.
  2. Optic Nerve: The photoreceptor cells in the retina send signals via the optic nerve to the brain.
  3. Optic Chiasm: The optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over at the optic chiasm.
  4. Optic Tract: The fibers continue along the optic tract, which carries visual information from each eye to the brain.
  5. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus: The optic tract fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
  6. Optic Radiation: From the lateral geniculate nucleus, the visual information is transmitted via the optic radiation fibers to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe of the brain.
  7. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex processes the visual information to create the perception of vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic tract: A lesion here would result in a homonymous hemianopsia, where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Option C. Optic radiations: A lesion in the optic radiations can cause a quadrant anopsia, affecting a specific quarter of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Occipital cortex: A lesion here could also cause homonymous hemianopsia, often with macular sparing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopsia, characterized by loss of the outer visual fields in both eyes, is typically caused by a lesion at the optic chiasma.

questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

 

Angle closure glaucoma is a condition where there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the closure of the angle between the iris and the cornea, which obstructs the drainage of aqueous humor. This leads to a rapid rise in IOP, resulting in acute, severe eye pain, headache, nausea, and a sudden loss of vision. A key clinical sign of an acute angle closure glaucoma attack is a mid-dilated, vertically oval, and sluggishly reacting pupil. The vertically oval pupil occurs due to ischemia of the iris sphincter muscles caused by the high IOP.

 

 

This condition is an ophthalmic emergency, and immediate treatment is necessary to prevent permanent vision loss. The high IOP can cause damage to the optic nerve, leading to irreversible vision loss if not promptly managed.

 

Note - Vogt's triad is a set of three clinical signs associated with the aftermath of an acute attack of glaucoma. This triad includes sphincter atrophy (damage to the iris sphincter muscle), a mid-dilated pupil that does not react well to light, and glaucoma flecken, which are patches of pigmentation or discoloration on the lens of the eye resulting from the damage caused by the increased intraocular pressure during a glaucoma attack.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR/Macular degeneration: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) and age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) are conditions that cause a gradual, painless loss of central vision. They do not present with acute pain, sudden vision loss, or pupillary abnormalities like a vertically oval pupil.

 

Option B. Cataract: Cataracts cause a gradual, painless decrease in vision due to the clouding of the lens. They do not cause sudden vision loss, pain, or changes in pupil shape.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause sudden vision loss and pain, particularly with eye movement. However, it does not cause changes in the shape of the pupil or a vertically oval pupil. The pain in optic neuritis is typically associated with eye movements rather than the constant severe pain seen in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A patient working in an iron factory presents with visual disturbance and is found to have iron deposits in the eye. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this ocular finding?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Siderosis bulbi

 

Siderosis bulbi is the condition where iron gets deposited in the eye due to the entry of an iron foreign body. This is commonly seen in industrial settings where iron is frequently used.

 

Ocular changes includes heterochromia (change in the color of the iris), iron deposits in the lens, uvea, and retina, leading to conditions like uveitis, retinitis, and even optic atrophy. These changes can result in severe visual impairment and blindness.

 

The condition can present immediately after the injury or even years later.

 

Severe cases can lead to phthisis bulbi, a condition where the eye becomes shrunken and non-functional.

 

The investigation of choice for detecting an iron foreign body is a CT scan or a B-scan ultrasound, as MRI is contraindicated due to the magnetic nature of iron.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chalcosis: This condition is caused by copper deposition in the eye. It is seen in cases involving copper foreign bodies.

 

Option C. Kayser-Fleischer ring: This is a brownish ring around the cornea seen in Wilson's disease, a condition involving copper metabolism disorder.

 

Option D. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a genetic disorder causing pigmentary dystrophy of the retina. It does not involve iron deposits and is unrelated to the occupational exposure described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Siderosis bulbi is caused by iron deposits in the eye, commonly seen in patients with a history of iron foreign body exposure, leading to significant ocular changes and potential blindness.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: What is the most common location of Scarpa’s Staphyloma? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior pole

 

Explanation:

 

Scarpa's Staphyloma (Posterior Staphyloma) typically develops at the posterior pole of the eye. It represents an outpouching of the posterior globe wall where the sclera becomes thinned and bulges outward due to intraocular pressure. While it's commonly associated with pathologic myopia, the specific location at the posterior pole is crucial for diagnosis and differentiation from other types of staphylomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal to optic disc: While staphylomas can extend to this region, the most common initial location is at the posterior pole. Temporal staphylomas are less common variants.

 

Option B. Around the optic nerve: Peripapillary staphylomas do exist but are a distinct entity from Scarpa's Staphyloma. They specifically involve the area immediately surrounding the optic nerve head rather than the broader posterior pole.

 

Option D. Inferior to macula: Inferior staphylomas are relatively rare. The characteristic location of Scarpa's Staphyloma is at the posterior pole, which includes the macular region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the typical anatomical location of Scarpa's Staphyloma at the posterior pole is crucial for proper diagnosis and differentiation from other types of staphylomas.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen’s chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

questions.text: In Horner syndrome, ptosis is seen. In this condition, which muscle is implicated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

 

 

Horner syndrome is a condition resulting from a lesion in the sympathetic pathway. It is characterized by a classical triad of symptoms:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) - Mild

 

Miosis (constricted pupil)

 

Anhidrosis (lack of sweating on the affected side of the face).

 

In this condition, ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which is a small muscle in the upper eyelid that is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system. The Muller's muscle is responsible for approximately 2 mm of eyelid elevation. When this muscle is affected, it leads to mild ptosis, which is a hallmark sign of Horner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LPS muscle: The Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) muscle is responsible for the major elevation of the upper eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not the sympathetic system. It is not implicated in Horner syndrome.

 

Option B. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It plays no role in eyelid elevation and is not involved in Horner syndrome.

 

Option D. Horner muscle: There is no muscle known as the "Horner muscle." This is not a correct anatomical term and does not pertain to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mild ptosis seen in Horner syndrome is due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which has sympathetic innervation and contributes to a small degree of eyelid elevation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old presents with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with chronic dacryocystitis, the treatment of choice is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). Chronic dacryocystitis involves the inflammation and obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, leading to persistent tearing and infection. In adults, this condition typically requires surgical intervention to create a new drainage pathway.

 

DCR surgery involves creating a passage between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. This bypasses the blocked nasolacrimal duct and allows tears to drain directly into the nose. The procedure effectively resolves the symptoms and prevents recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lacrimal sac massage: This is typically recommended for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants, not for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option B. Syringing: This procedure can help to diagnose the site of obstruction and may be used in cases of acute dacryocystitis or in infants, but it is not a definitive treatment for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option D. Probing: This is also more commonly used in infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In adults, especially those with chronic inflammation, probing alone is usually insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis in adults, involving the creation of a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity to bypass the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with visual acuity of 6/18, which improves upon performing the pinhole test. During the examination, the presence of fibrosis in the lens nucleus is noted, and his near vision displays improvement. Based on these findings, what is the refractive error he is presenting with? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Index myopia

 

The improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is referred to as the "second sight phenomenon", given in the clinical picture, which is suggestive of index myopia. It manifests as index myopia as a result of nuclear cataract production.

 

MYOPIA - Parallel rays of light are brought into focus in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest. This is also called short sightedness or near sightedness.

 

Types –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Index hypermetropia: This would involve a decrease in the refractive index, leading to farsightedness, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. Presbyopia: This is an age-related condition causing difficulty in near vision due to the lens losing its flexibility. It does not explain the improvement in near vision or the findings of lens fibrosis.

 

Option D. Axial myopia: This is due to an increase in the length of the eyeball and would not be associated with the fibrosis of the lens nucleus or the improvement in near vision seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Index myopia is characterized by an increase in the refractive index of the lens nucleus, often associated with nuclear sclerosis in cataracts, and can result in the "second sight phenomenon," where near vision temporarily improves

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

 

  • Image shows neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, arising from optic nerve head.
  • Neovascularization of the disc (ND). and along large vessels, as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) present.
  • Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of ischaemic areas.
  • Aim is to reduce metabolic demand and prevent release of vasoproliferative factors.

 

 

Birdshot retinochoroidopathy (also known as birdshot chorioretinopathy, vitiliginous chorioretinitis, or simply birdshot uveitis) is a chronic, bilateral, posterior uveitis with characteristic yellow-white lesions in the fundus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - Characterized by microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages but does not feature neovascularization.

 

Option B. Severe Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - More extensive than mild, including hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and sometimes severe retinal ischemia, but still lacks neovascularization.

 

Option C. Birdshot Choroidopathy - Typically presents with distinctive yellow-white lesions in the retina, which are not apparent in the provided angiography images. This condition is an inflammatory process, not related to neovascularization seen in diabetic retinopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss. It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.

questions.text: Which of the following favors a diagnosis of scleritis over episcleritis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe pain and tenderness

 

Explanation:

 

Severe pain and tenderness are hallmark features of scleritis, distinguishing it from episcleritis. The pain in scleritis is typically intense and may radiate to the periorbital area due to deeper tissue inflammation affecting the dense sensory nerve supply of the sclera. This severe discomfort, along with marked tenderness to palpation, reflects the more serious nature of scleritis compared to the milder symptoms of episcleritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vessels that blanch with phenylephrine: This is characteristic of episcleritis, not scleritis. In episcleritis, the superficial vessels respond to vasoconstrictor drops, while in scleritis, the deeper vessels do not blanch.

 

Option C. Mobile superficial vessels: Mobility of vessels with a cotton bud tip suggests episcleritis, where only superficial vessels are involved. In scleritis, the vessels are typically immobile due to deeper tissue involvement.

 

Option D. Pink discoloration only: Mild pink discoloration is more typical of episcleritis. Scleritis usually presents with a deeper, violaceous hue due to involvement of deeper vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding that severe pain and tenderness are key diagnostic features of scleritis, helping differentiate it from the milder presentation of episcleritis.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below. The given FFA is characteristic of which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macular ischemia

 

  • The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia (see the images below).
  • The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyper fluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

 

 

  • The FFA is showing enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow).
  • Both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular edema: shows the characteristic petaloid appearance.

 

Option C. Submacular/subretinal hemorrhage: obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary non-perfusion but spreads across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.

 

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage/ vitreous hemorrhage: obscure the visualization of even retinal vasculature and would appear as a region of hypo fluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macular ischemia in diabetic patients can be identified in FFA images by an enlarged foveal avascular zone and visible areas of capillary non-perfusion, key indicators of decreased vascular supply to the macula.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner plexiform layer

 

The inner plexiform layer is marked in the above histological image of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner plexiform layer of the retina is a crucial site for synaptic activity among various retinal cells, playing a key role in the preprocessing of visual information before it is sent to the brain. Recognizing this layer and understanding its function are important for comprehending the overall neural circuitry of the retina.

questions.text: Which abbreviation is used to denote "Both Eyes" in ophthalmology prescriptions? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OU

 

Explanation:

 

"Oculus Uterque" (OU) is the Latin term used in ophthalmology to refer to both eyes. The terminology comes from Latin, where "Oculus" means "eye" and "Uterque" means "both." This is a standard notation used in medical records and prescriptions related to eye care.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OD (Oculus Dexter): This refers specifically to the right eye only.

 

Option B. OS (Oculus Sinister): This refers specifically to the left eye only.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as OU is the correct abbreviation for both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding that "Oculus Uterque" (OU) is the proper medical terminology used to denote both eyes in ophthalmic prescriptions and documentation

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

An oil drop cataract is a specific type of cataract that is characteristically seen in patients with galactosemia. Galactosemia is an inherited disorder of galactose metabolism, where the body is unable to properly process galactose, a sugar found in milk. As a result of the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens of the eye, a cataract forms that resembles an oil droplet when viewed under certain lighting conditions. This cataract is often congenital or develops early in life, making it a common cause of pediatric cataracts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. While it affects various organs, it does not typically cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Option C. Tay-Sachs disease: Tay-Sachs disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. It primarily affects the central nervous system and does not cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil drop cataracts are a hallmark feature of galactosemia, an inherited disorder affecting galactose metabolism, and they can present as congenital or developmental cataracts in pediatric patients.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with antibodies against acetylcholine receptors and complaints of muscle weakness. He is diagnosed to have myasthenia gravis. Which diagnostic test will best confirm ocular myasthenia gravis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tensilon test

 

Explanation:

 

The Tensilon (edrophonium) test is the most specific diagnostic test for confirming ocular myasthenia gravis. When administered intravenously:

  1. It acts as a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor
  2. Shows rapid improvement in ptosis and/or diplopia within 30-60 seconds
  3. The improvement is temporary, lasting only a few minutes
  4. Provides objective confirmation of the diagnosis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ice pack test: While useful as a bedside test for myasthenia gravis, it is less specific and reliable compared to the Tensilon test.

 

Option B. Force duction test: This test evaluates mechanical restrictions of extraocular muscles and is not specific for neuromuscular junction disorders.

 

Option D. Forced generation test: This evaluates muscle strength against resistance and is not specific for diagnosing myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding that the Tensilon test is the most specific diagnostic test for confirming ocular myasthenia gravis, showing temporary improvement in symptoms due to increased acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

 

The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

 

  • Patients are shown a picture of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held about 16 inches in front of the patient's eyes.
  • Patients are asked to wear polarized glasses during the test.
  • Normal perception of depth will cause the housefly to appear as a 3D image above the plane.
  • Patients will attempt to pinch the wings of the housefly in the air, above the plane of the image, if perception of depth is normal.
  • Defective perception of depth will cause the image to appear as a normal 2D image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular deviation: This refers to misalignment of the eyes, typically tested with cover tests or Hirschberg test, not the Titmus stereotest.

 

Option C. Refractive errors: These are assessed with vision tests using an eye chart, not stereopsis tests.

 

Option D. Colour Blindness: This is assessed using color vision tests like the Ishihara test, not related to depth perception tests like the Titmus stereotest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Titmus stereotest evaluates stereopsis or depth perception, an essential aspect of binocular vision, allowing for the three-dimensional interpretation of the world necessary for various activities and indicating healthy, cooperative eye function.

questions.text: A patient has a field defect where he cannot see the left side from the left eye and the left side from the right eye, that is from both the eyes the patient is not able to look towards the left, with preserved central vision. What is the field defect?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Explanation:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is a type of visual field defect where the patient cannot see the same side of the visual field in both eyes, but central vision is preserved.

 

This condition typically indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically on the side opposite to the visual field loss. In this case, the patient cannot see the left side from both eyes, which means the lesion is in the right occipital lobe. The occipital lobe processes visual information, and a lesion here can result in loss of vision in the corresponding visual field of both eyes.

 

Macular sparing occurs because the macular region of the occipital cortex has a dual blood supply from both the middle cerebral artery and the posterior cerebral artery, providing some redundancy that preserves central vision even when other parts of the occipital lobe are damaged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quadrantanopia: This refers to the loss of vision in one quadrant (one-fourth) of the visual field. It is not consistent with the described field defect involving half of the visual field.

 

Option C. Homonymous hemianopia: This is the loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes without the specification of macular sparing. The inclusion of macular sparing helps to localize the lesion more specifically to the occipital lobe.

 

Option D. Bitemporal hemianopia: This is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes, typically due to a lesion at the optic chiasm. It does not fit the description where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe on the side opposite to the visual field.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: During an ophthalmic examination, the patient is asked to direct her gaze to her right side. During this ocular movement, the right lateral rectus muscle is being used. Which of the following is its yoke muscle?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left medial rectus

 

Left medial rectus and Right lateral Rectus are yoke muscles.

 

Yoke muscle - contralaterally paired extraocular muscles that works synergistically to direct the gaze in a given direction. For example, in directing the gaze to the right, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus operate together as yoke muscles.

 

Examples:

 

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. It is not the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Right medial rectus: This muscle is responsible for adduction of the right eye, not synergistic with the right lateral rectus during rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left lateral rectus: This muscle is responsible for abduction of the left eye and would work with the right medial rectus for leftward gaze, not rightward gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles from opposite eyes that work together to direct the gaze in a specific direction. For rightward gaze, the yoke muscles are the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus.

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is seen in ocular blunt trauma?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

A rosette cataract, also known as a traumatic cataract, is a specific type of cataract that can occur as a result of ocular blunt trauma. When the eye experiences blunt trauma, such as a direct blow or impact, it can cause disruption or damage to the lens fibers, leading to the formation of a characteristic star-shaped opacity within the lens.

 

The term "rosette" refers to the appearance of the cataract, which resembles a flower-like pattern with radiating spokes or lines extending from a central point.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxic cataract: This type of cataract is caused by exposure to toxic substances, such as certain medications, chemicals, or radiation.

 

Option B. Metabolic cataract: Metabolic cataracts develop due to systemic metabolic disorders, such as diabetes or galactosemia, which affect the metabolism of the lens proteins.

 

Option D. Nuclear cataract: Nuclear cataract affects the central portion of the lens (nucleus) and is associated with aging. It causes gradual clouding and yellowing of the lens nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is commonly seen in ocular blunt trauma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.

 

A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spring catarrh

 

A shield ulcer, is a specific type of corneal ulcer characterized by its unique shape resembling a shield or crescent. These ulcers typically occur in the peripheral cornea and are often associated with certain inflammatory or allergic conditions of the eye, such as vernal keratoconjunctivitis (spring catarrh) or atopic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva characterized by the formation of small, raised lesions called phlyctenules. These lesions can occur on the conjunctiva or cornea and are often associated with underlying conditions such as tuberculosis or staphylococcal infection.

 

Option C. Atopic keratoconjunctivitis - Atopic keratoconjunctivitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva and cornea that occurs in individuals with a history of atopic dermatitis (eczema) or other allergic conditions. It is characterized by severe itching, papillary conjunctivitis, and corneal involvement, which may include the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Option D. Cataract - Cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye that leads to a decrease in vision. While cataracts can cause various visual disturbances, they are not typically associated with the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spring catarrh, also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic allergic condition of the conjunctiva that typically occurs in children and young adults during the spring and summer months. It is characterized by symptoms such as itching, redness, and photophobia, and may lead to the development of shield ulcers on the cornea.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enlarged blind spots

 

The correct answer is Enlarged blind spots. The image shows a significant enlargement of the physiological blind spot, which is a hallmark of conditions such as papilledema. Papilledema is a condition characterized by optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling leads to an enlarged blind spot-on visual field testing, which is prominently seen in the images provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Altitudinal field defects: These defects present as a loss of vision above or below the horizontal line, resembling a band-like defect across the visual field. This type of defect is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy or branch retinal artery or vein occlusion.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate field defects: Arcuate defects appear as arc-shaped visual losses that extend from the blind spot and follow the nerve fiber layer pattern. This type of defect is typically seen in glaucoma and other optic neuropathies.

 

 

Option D. Roennes nasal step: This defect is characterized by a step-like pattern near the nasal visual field, commonly seen in glaucoma. It occurs due to the asymmetry between the superior and inferior nerve fiber bundles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlarged blind spots on visual field testing are indicative of conditions like papilledema, where optic disc swelling leads to an increased physiological blind spot

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis.
  • Usually occurs after penetrative trauma or intraocular surgery.
  • Both eyes develop panuveitis: the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye).
  • Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.
  • The most accepted theory is the allergic theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye.
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury.
  • Earliest symptoms in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    •  Photophobia
  • Earliest sign in uninjured eye: Retrolental flare.
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation (not evisceration) of an injured eye in order to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.

 

   

 

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) and sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) are bilateral, autoimmune granulomatous intraocular inflammatory conditions with nearly identical findings on ophthalmic exam. Both can reveal serous retinal detachments, optic disc edema, vitritis, and Dalen-Fuchs nodules, but they differ in key facets such as a history of penetrating ocular injury in SO and greater systemic associations in VKH. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis involves inflammation limited to the anterior part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and does not typically follow the pattern seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis, which affects the entire uveal tract.

 

Option B. Pars planitis: Pars planitis is a form of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the peripheral retina and pars plana. It does not encompass the entire uveal tract as in panuveitis.

 

Option D. Chronic anterior uveitis: Chronic anterior uveitis is a long-standing inflammation of the anterior uvea, typically affecting only the iris and ciliary body, not the entire uveal tract as seen in panuveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) After cataract

 

(SYNONYMS: POSTERIOR CAPSULAR OPACIFICATION/SECOND CATARACT)

 

  • Elschnig's pearls are a type of after cataract, a delayed complication of cataract surgery.
  • They are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

Types of after cataract:

 

  • ﻿﻿Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • ﻿﻿Dense membranous after-cataract
  • ﻿﻿Soemmering ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • ﻿Elschnig's pearls

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irvine-Gass syndrome:

 

  • Postoperative cystoid macular edema classically described as vitreous touch syndrome.
  • Can occur upto 6 months post cataract surgery.
  • Resolves on its own.
  • Non resolving Irvine Gass syndrome is treated with topical NSAID eye drops, intra and periocular steroid injection and intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection.

 

Option C. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Caused by an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becoming trapped within the capsular bag
  • Characterized by pain and redness
  • Delayed complication
  • Treatment is removal of entire IOL-Bag complex along with vitrectomy and secondary IOL implantation – either sclera fixation / iris claw IOL / Anterior chamber IOL.

 

Option D. Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome:

 

  • Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously
  • Seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation
  • Also seen when foldable hydrophilic IOL is implanted in ciliary sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).
