Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor.
  • It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  • The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
    1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
    2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
    3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
    4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Note: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can occur in various glands in the body, including the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by slow growth and the tendency to invade nearby structures.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is another type of malignant tumor that can affect the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by a combination of mucin-secreting and squamous (epidermoid) cells.

 

Option D. Malignant mixed tumor: Malignant mixed tumor, also known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, occurs when a previously benign pleomorphic adenoma transforms into a malignant tumor. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma but represents a more aggressive form of lacrimal gland tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

 

Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

 

Corneal tattooing was introduced as an attempt to mask the leukomatous opacities of the eye during ancient times. Corneal tattooing is also found to reduce glare within the eye due to iris loss and increase visual acuity.

 

Many different types of inks are used throughout history and today for the dyeing of the cornea. Today, India ink is the most commonly used, providing safe and long-lasting effects, but other dyes include metallic colors in powder form, various organic dyes, and uveal pigment from animal eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fincham's test: Used specifically to evaluate differences in the nature of halos seen by patients, aiding in the differential diagnosis between cataract and glaucoma.

 

Option C. Optical Iridectomy: The stenopaeic slit assists in locating the best area on the cornea for performing an iridectomy, essential in cases where peripheral vision needs to be preserved.

 

Option D. To find out the axis in astigmatism: It is instrumental in determining the precise axis for corrective lenses, which is vital for proper astigmatism management.

 

STENOPAEIC SLIT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

 

  • Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism.

questions.text: A patient of HIV with low CD4 count presents with the following finding. Which of the following is used in the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a case of retinitis, a common ocular manifestation in HIV patients with low CD4 counts.

 

Retinitis can be caused by various pathogens, but in the context of HIV with a low CD4 count, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is a significant concern. This condition is typically seen when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³. CMV retinitis presents with retinal necrosis and can progress rapidly, leading to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice for CMV retinitis is Ganciclovir, which can be administered intravitreally to deliver the drug directly to the affected site in the eye. Ganciclovir inhibits viral replication by targeting viral DNA polymerase, making it effective against CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: This antiviral is used primarily for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infections.

 

Option B. Valacyclovir: This is a prodrug of acyclovir and is also used for HSV and VZV infections.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: This antiviral is used in the treatment of HIV and Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for CMV retinitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, administered intravitreally to manage the infection effectively and prevent blindness.

 

Additional Information

Ocular manifestation of HIV –

questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

Lesion at the level of the optic chiasma causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Hence, the lesion at this level produces bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Common causes of the central chiasmal lesion are as follows:

 

  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Tumors of the pituitary gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma
  • Glioma of the third ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma - This refers to a loss of vision in the central visual field and is typically associated with diseases affecting the macula or the optic nerve, not lesions at the chiasm.

 

Option B. Bilateral Hemianopia - This would involve a loss of vision in the same half of the visual field of each eye (either left or right), which generally occurs with lesions affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe, not the chiasm.

 

Option C. Binasal Hemianopia - This visual field defect involves loss of vision in the nasal halves (the sides closest to the nose) of both eyes, which is uncommon and would more likely result from unusual patterns of optic nerve damage rather than a central chiasmal lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasm, often caused by conditions like pituitary tumors or chiasmal compression. This key symptom helps in diagnosing issues that may require urgent intervention to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text: Which among the following is a characteristic early finding in retinitis pigmentosa? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormal scotopic ERG

 

Explanation:

 

Early retinitis pigmentosa predominantly affects rods before cones, making abnormal scotopic ERG an early characteristic finding. The sequence of ERG changes in retinitis pigmentosa typically follows:

  1. Early disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) responses
  2. Disease progression: Reduction in combined responses
  3. Advanced disease: Reduced photopic responses
  4. End-stage: Extinguished ERG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal pigmentation in periphery: While characteristic of RP, bone-spicule pigmentation typically appears later in the disease course, often years after functional changes are detectable on ERG.

 

Option B. Pale waxy disc: This is a late finding that occurs after significant retinal degeneration has already taken place.

 

Option C. Abnormal photopic ERG: Photopic (cone) responses typically become abnormal later in the disease course, after rod dysfunction is well established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding that abnormal scotopic ERG is an early finding in retinitis pigmentosa, often preceding visible fundus changes and reflecting the primary involvement of rods in the disease process.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child’s father brought him for checkup. On examination, there was white pupillary reflex. USG findings shows intraocular mass with calcification in the eye. There is a family history of enucleation. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that typically presents in young children. It often presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may be associated with an intraocular mass with calcification. There is also a familial predisposition to retinoblastoma, which is indicated by the family history of enucleation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative retinal detachment is a condition where fluid accumulates under the retina, leading to detachment. It is not typically associated with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option B. Pediatric tuberculosis: Pediatric tuberculosis can affect various organs, including the eyes, but it usually presents with other signs and symptoms such as fever, cough, and weight loss. It is unlikely to present with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of prematurity: Retinopathy of prematurity is a condition affecting premature infants and is characterized by abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina. It does not typically present with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma should be considered in a young child with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification, especially in the presence of a family history of enucleation.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: What is the center for vertical gaze? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal

 

Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the center for vertical gaze.

 

There are "centers" that control conjugate eye movements. The supranuclear centers are in the cerebral cortex.

 

  • The frontal cortex has an area that controls quick fixational eye movements to the opposite side.
  • The occipital cortex has an area that controls slow pursuit eye movements to the ipsilateral or same side.
  • Both supranuclear areas send impulses to the brainstem and to the centers that control conjugate eye movements.
  • The centers controlling eye movements in the brainstem are the final common pathway conveying impulses for movement in a particular direction.
  • The center controlling horizontal conjugate movements is the pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF), and it controls conjugate horizontal movement to the ipsilateral side.
  • An area controlling vertical movements lies just above the two-third nerve nuclei and is involved in the early development of pinealoma.
  • The center for convergence (Perlia nucleus) is associated with the third nerve nucleus and lies in the region of the Edinger-Westphal complex and an area coordinating divergence possibly exists.

 

 

  • In contrast to horizontal gaze, which is generated by unilateral aggregates of cerebral and pontine neurons, vertical eye movements, with few exceptions, are under bilateral control of the cerebral cortex and upper brainstem.
  • The groups of nerve cells and fibers that govern upward and downward gaze, as well as torsional saccades, are situated in the pretectal areas of the midbrain and involve three integrated structures-
    1. The riMLF (rostral interstitial nucleus of the MLF).
    2. The INC (interstitial nucleus of Cajal)
    3. The nucleus and fibers of the posterior commissure (PC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation: Primarily responsible for horizontal gaze movements, particularly conjugate gaze to the ipsilateral side.

 

Option B. Raphe Nucleus: Involved in serotonin production and has a role in sleep and mood regulation, not directly involved in vertical gaze.

 

Option D. Nucleus of Perlia: Often associated with convergence but its exact role and existence are somewhat controversial and less defined in literature compared to well-defined structures like the INC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (INC) is the central control site for vertical gaze movements in the brainstem, playing a critical role in coordinating upward and downward eye movements.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate surgical treatment for severe ptosis (>4mm) with poor levator function in Horner's syndrome? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontalis sling operation

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of severe ptosis with poor levator function, regardless of the underlying cause (including Horner's syndrome), a frontalis sling operation is the procedure of choice. This procedure is indicated when:

  1. Ptosis is severe (>4mm)
  2. Levator function is poor (<4mm)
  3. Conservative management has failed

 

The frontalis sling procedure connects the tarsus of the upper eyelid to the frontalis muscle, effectively using the frontalis muscle's action to assist in eyelid elevation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levator resection: While useful for moderate ptosis, it requires at least fair levator function to be effective. Not suitable for cases with poor levator function.

 

Option C. Fasanella servat operation: This is only suitable for mild ptosis (<2mm) with good levator function. It would be inadequate for severe ptosis.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as frontalis sling operation is a well-established treatment for severe ptosis with poor levator function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding that the severity of ptosis and the degree of levator function, rather than the underlying cause, determines the choice of surgical procedure. Frontalis sling operation is the treatment of choice for severe ptosis with poor levator function.
